questions.text: The production of which of the following hormones is increased in obesity? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Insulin

 

In obesity, there is typically an increase in insulin production due to insulin resistance. This resistance at the cellular level leads to impaired glucose uptake by cells, prompting the pancreas to secrete more insulin in an attempt to maintain normal blood glucose levels—a state referred to as compensatory hyperinsulinemia. Over time, this can strain the pancreas and exacerbate metabolic issues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thyroxine: Thyroxine levels are generally not increased in obesity; thyroid function can sometimes be altered, but not in the manner of increased production directly due to obesity.

 

Option C. Growth hormone: Growth hormone levels are often decreased in obesity. Growth hormone has lipolytic effects, helping to break down fats, and its lower levels in obesity are associated with an adverse metabolic profile.

 

Option D. Adiponectin: This is a hormone produced by adipose tissue that enhances insulin sensitivity and has anti-inflammatory effects. Levels of adiponectin are typically lower in individuals with obesity, which contributes to increased insulin resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In obesity, insulin resistance occurring due defect at receptors which causes compensatory hyperinsulinemia. Thyroxine, growth hormone, and adiponectin have lipolytic effects, hence, their levels are reduced in obesity.

 

Reference - Harrison/Obesity

questions.text: What levels of prolactin are definitely suggestive of prolactinoma? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. > 200 ug/L

 

Prolactin levels greater than 200 ug/L are definitely suggestive of a prolactinoma. This level typically indicates the presence of a prolactin-secreting pituitary adenoma. The significant elevation in prolactin can cause clinical symptoms such as galactorrhea and amenorrhea in women, or hypogonadism in men. The diagnosis is further supported by imaging studies such as MRI, which can visualize the adenoma.

 

Additional Information

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is most commonly associated with a hypercoagulable state? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Factor V mutation

 

Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited cause of hypercoagulability. It should be suspected in young patients (<50 years) presenting with thrombotic manifestations.

 

  • It is caused by substitution in the Factor V gene (Factor V Leiden mutation)
  • Causes enhanced coagulability in patients
  • In heterozygous condition, increases risk of thrombus formation by 4-5 times
  • In homozygous condition, increases risk by 50 times

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antithrombin III deficiency 

 

  • Although this can cause thrombosis, it is less common than Factor V Leiden mutation
  • Antithrombin III acts as a natural anticoagulant
  • Its deficiency is rarer compared to Factor V Leiden mutation

 

Option C. Factor XIII deficiency

 

  • Factor XIII is involved in clot stabilization
  • Its deficiency causes bleeding rather than thrombosis
  • Characterized by umbilical cord bleeding in newborns

 

Option D. Factor XII deficiency 

 

  • Factor XII initiates intrinsic pathway of coagulation
  • Its deficiency does not cause significant bleeding
  • Not typically associated with hypercoagulable states

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited cause of hypercoagulable states, increasing thrombosis risk 4-5 times in heterozygous and 50 times in homozygous individuals.

questions.text: What is the most common site for an extragonadal germ cell tumor? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mediastinum

 

Extragonadal germ cell tumor is most commonly seen in mediastinum.

 

Extragonadal germinal cell tumors (EGGCTs) are rare tumors that predominantly affect young males.

 

These tumors are particularly significant because they mimic the normal germ cell tumors but appear in unusual locations, making them a critical diagnostic challenge. The prevalence of EGGCTs in the mediastinum indicates the importance of considering this location when evaluating patients with symptoms suggestive of germ cell tumors but without testicular or ovarian masses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pineal gland: While EGGCTs can occur here, they represent only about 5% of cases.

 

Option B. Retroperitoneum: This site accounts for 30-40% of EGGCT cases, making it the second most common site.

 

Option C. Sacrococcygeal region: This is the least common site.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Common sites of extragonadal germ cell tumor –

 

  • Mediastinum (50-70%)
  • Retroperitoneum (30-40%)
  • Pineal gland (5%)
  • Sacrococcygeal area (less than 5%)

questions.text: A 22-year-old patient has fever with severe shortness of breath and red currant jelly sputum. On examination, he has altered sensorium with a respiratory rate of 35 breaths/min. Lab investigations show serum creatinine of 1.9 mg/dL. CXR is done and shows multi-lobar infiltrates. What is correct regarding the management? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ICU management (IV drugs)

 

Explanation

 

The patient presents with severe symptoms of community-acquired pneumonia, including fever, severe shortness of breath, red currant jelly sputum, altered sensorium, a high respiratory rate, and multi-lobar infiltrates on the chest X-ray.

 

The CURB-65 score and IDSA/ATS guidelines for severe community-acquired pneumonia suggest that patients with severe symptoms, especially those meeting major criteria or multiple minor criteria, require intensive care unit (ICU) management.

 

CURB-65 Criteria (score 0-5)

 

  • Confusion
  • Uremia (BUN > 19 mg/dL or Urea >40 mg/dL)
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 30/min
  • Blood pressure (systolic < 90 mmHg or diastolic ≤ 60 mmHg)
  • Age ≥ 65 years

 

The patient scores high on these criteria due to confusion, high respiratory rate, and multi-lobar infiltrates.

 

IDSA/ATS Criteria for Severe CAP

 

Minor Criteria

 

  • Respiratory rate ≥ 30 breaths/min
  • PaO2/FiO2 ratio ≤ 250
  • Multi-lobar infiltrates
  • Confusion/disorientation
  • Uremia (BUN level ≥ 20 mg/dL)
  • Leukopenia (WBC count < 4000 cells/mm3)
  • Thrombocytopenia (platelet count < 100,000 cells/mm3)
  • Hypothermia (core temperature < 36°C)
  • Hypotension requiring aggressive fluid resuscitation

 

Major Criteria

 

  • Septic shock requiring vasopressors
  • Respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation

 

The patient meets several minor criteria, indicating severe CAP requiring ICU admission and intravenous antibiotics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. OPD management: Not appropriate for severe symptoms and high CURB-65 score.

 

Option B. IPD management: While necessary, ICU care is more appropriate.

 

Option C. ICU management (oral drugs): IV drugs are required for severe cases in the ICU.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with severe community-acquired pneumonia, especially those with altered sensorium, high respiratory rate, and multi-lobar infiltrates, should be managed in the ICU with intravenous antibiotics.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient with a history of abdominal pain and fever for the past three days presents to the hospital. The physician orders a chest X-ray in the erect position which shows abnormal findings. Based on these findings, the most likely diagnosis will be determined? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hollow viscus perforation

 

  • Air under the diaphragm is seen in the given erect radiograph, which is a characteristic finding of hollow viscus perforation.
  •  Perforation of a viscus can lead to peritonitis, which is inflammation of the peritoneum due to the spillage of fluids into the peritoneal cavity or secondary bacterial infection.
  • Clinical features of hollow viscus perforation include abdominal pain, distension, nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, tenderness, rebound tenderness, and guarding on palpation.
  •  Fever may also be present, and septic shock can occur in later stages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastric volvulus: Gastric volvulus refers to the twisting of the stomach on its axis. It can result in obstruction and ischemia. Symptoms include severe epigastric pain, vomiting, and difficulty in passing a nasogastric tube. On imaging, the stomach may be abnormally positioned, often with a characteristic appearance described as an "inverted stomach" or "upside-down stomach." While it can cause serious complications, air under the diaphragm on an erect chest radiograph is not typically associated with gastric volvulus.

 

Option C. Liver abscess: A liver abscess is typically caused by bacterial or amoebic infection. Symptoms include fever, abdominal pain, jaundice, and weight loss. An erect chest radiograph isn't the primary modality to diagnose a liver abscess. Instead, an ultrasound or CT scan of the abdomen would be more appropriate to visualize an abscess within the liver.

 

Option D. Empyema thoracis: Empyema refers to the accumulation of pus in the pleural cavity (space between the lung and the chest wall). It's usually a complication of pneumonia or thoracic surgery. Symptoms include fever, cough, chest pain, and breathlessness. On a chest radiograph, the empyema may appear as a fluid level or a white opacity, depending on its stage and the amount of fluid. An erect chest X-ray may be used to diagnose empyema, but it would not typically show free air under the diaphragm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Air under the diaphragm seen on an erect chest radiograph is a hallmark finding of a hollow viscus perforation, which is a surgical emergency requiring immediate attention to prevent peritonitis and other severe complications.

choices.text: Mixed cellar type
Nodular sclerosis
Lymphocyte predominant
Classical Hodgkin Lymphoma

questions.text: L & H type Reed-Sternberg (RS) cell is seen in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lymphocyte predominant

 

In lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma, L and H type Reed-Sternberg cells are seen.

 

It is distinguished by the presence of lymphohistiocytic (L&H) variant RS cells, also known as LP cells, with a delicate multilobed, puffy nucleus that resembles popped corn (popcorn cell). Other reactive cells, such as eosinophils, are scarce or absent, and RS cells are uncommon.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Mixed cell type, B. Nodular sclerosis and D. Classical Hodgkin Lymphoma: These categories of Hodgkin lymphoma typically feature classical RS cells which express CD15 and CD30 and do not have the popcorn-like appearance of the L&H variant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

L & H type Reed-Sternberg cells, displaying a popcorn-like appearance and expressing B-cell markers, are a hallmark of lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma.

questions.text: Which of the following has autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cystic fibrosis

 

Cystic fibrosis: Cystic fibrosis is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means that an individual needs to inherit two copies of the altered gene (one from each parent) to manifest the condition.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Achondroplasia: Achondroplasia is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, meaning that having one copy of the altered gene is sufficient to express the condition.

 

Option B. Huntington’s disease: Huntington's disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern as well, where one copy of the altered gene is enough to cause the disease.

 

Option D. Familial Hypercholesterolemia: Familial Hypercholesterolemia is typically inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, but there are rare cases of autosomal recessive inheritance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

AD (Autosomal Dominant)                                                                                       

  • Familial hypercholesterolemia
  • Huntington's disease
  • Lactose Intolerance
  • Marfan Syndrome
  • Myotonic Dystrophy
  • AD Polycystic Kidney Disease
  • Porphyria Variegate

 

AR (Autosomal Recessive)

  • Ataxia Telangiectasia
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Familial Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy
  • Sickle Cell disease
  • Thalassemia
  • Maple Syrup Urine disease
  • Homocystinuria
  • Alkaptonuria
  • Hemochromatosis
  • Albinism
  • Phenylketonuria
  • Wilson's disease
  • Hemochromatosis
  • AR Polycystic Kidney disease
  • Orotic Aciduria
  • Glycogen Storage Diseases
  • All Mucopolysaccharidosis (except Hunter’s)
  • All sphingolipidosis except Fabry’s disease

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 478

questions.text: What enzyme analysis will be done in a patient before starting anti-malarial drugs who had a family history of hemolytic anemia? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) G6PD analysis

 

G6PD (Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase) deficiency is the most common enzyme deficiency leading to hemolytic anemia. The enzyme G6PD is crucial in the HMP pathway, producing NADPH which is essential for:

 

  1. Converting oxidized glutathione to reduced glutathione in RBCs
  2. Protecting RBCs from oxidative stress
  3. Neutralizing harmful peroxides

 

When G6PD is deficient:

 

  • Reduced glutathione cannot be produced
  • RBCs become susceptible to oxidative stress
  • Hemolysis occurs when exposed to oxidative agents like antimalarial drugs
  • Being X-linked recessive, it shows family history and affects males more than females

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pyruvate kinase:

 

  • While this is the second most common enzyme deficiency causing hemolytic anemia, it's not specifically triggered by antimalarial drugs
  • Shows decreased RBC lactate levels, unlike G6PD deficiency where lactate levels are increased

 

Option C. Hexokinase:

 

  • First enzyme of glycolysis
  • Not specifically related to drug-induced hemolysis

 

Option D. Enolase:

 

  • Glycolytic enzyme converting 2-phosphoglycerate to phosphoenolpyruvate
  • Not related to drug-induced hemolysis

 

Educational Objective:

 

G6PD analysis must be done before starting antimalarial therapy in patients with family history of hemolytic anemia, as G6PD deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder where antimalarial drugs can trigger severe hemolysis due to oxidative stress.

questions.text: Match the following disorders with their respective clinical features or lab findings: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 → A, 2 → C, 3 → B, 4 → D

 

The matching of disorders with their respective clinical features or lab findings is based on the specific enzymatic defects associated with each type of glycogen storage disease (GSD).

 

  1. Cori’s Disease (Type III GSD):
    • Correct Match: A. Branched structure in liver biopsy
    • In Cori’s disease, the deficiency of the debranching enzyme leads to the accumulation of abnormal glycogen with short outer branches, often referred to as "limit dextrin." This structural abnormality can be observed in a liver biopsy.
       
  2. McArdle’s Disease (Type V GSD):
    • Correct Match: C. Exercise intolerance
    • McArdle’s disease is caused by a deficiency in muscle phosphorylase (myophosphorylase), which is required for glycogen breakdown in muscle tissue. As a result, individuals with McArdle’s disease experience exercise intolerance due to the inability to produce adequate energy during physical activity.
       
  3. Pompe’s Disease (Type II GSD):
    • Correct Match: B. Accumulation of glycogen in lysosome
    • Pompe’s disease is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme acid maltase (alpha-glucosidase), which leads to the accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes. This condition is also classified as a lysosomal storage disease.
       
  4. Von Gierke’s Disease (Type I GSD):
    • Correct Match: D. Hypoglycemia with lactic acidosis
    • Von Gierke’s disease results from a deficiency in glucose-6-phosphatase, an enzyme critical for gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis. The lack of this enzyme leads to severe fasting hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, and hepatomegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycogen storage diseases (GSDs) are classified based on the specific enzyme deficiency involved, leading to distinct clinical features such as exercise intolerance in McArdle’s disease, glycogen accumulation in lysosomes in Pompe’s disease, and hypoglycemia with lactic acidosis in Von Gierke’s disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered the initial recommended test for diagnosing pheochromocytoma? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 24 hr urinary total metanephrines

 

The 24-hour urinary metanephrines test is considered the gold standard and first-line test for diagnosing pheochromocytoma in the general population. The test should include fractionated catecholamines for comprehensive evaluation. This test is preferred due to its high sensitivity and specificity in detecting these rare neuroendocrine tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MIBG scan: This is a nuclear medicine imaging test that can be useful for localizing pheochromocytoma and ruling out multifocal or metastatic disease, but it's not the initial diagnostic test. It's typically performed after biochemical confirmation of the disease.

 

Option C. Plasma catecholamines: While plasma catecholamines can be measured as part of the routine testing, they are not as reliable as urinary metanephrines due to their fluctuating levels and potential for false positives.

 

Option D. MRI of the whole abdomen: This is an imaging study used for tumor localization after biochemical confirmation of pheochromocytoma. It's not appropriate as an initial diagnostic test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A 24-hour urinary metanephrines test with fractionated catecholamines is the initial recommended test for diagnosing pheochromocytoma in the general population. Plasma metanephrines can be considered in high-risk populations (such as those with a family history or genetic syndromes).

choices.text: Test stool for giardia and give antibiotics
Dried spot sample for HIV DNA PCR

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant born to an HIV-positive mother presents with recurrent diarrhea. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dried spot sample for HIV DNA PCR

 

In the given clinical scenario, it is important to establish or rule out a diagnosis of HIV infection before evaluating for secondary infections. Therefore, the next best step is to obtain a dried spot sample for HIV DNA PCR. AIDS enteropathy, a syndrome of malabsorption with partial villous atrophy not associated with a specific pathogen, has been postulated to be a result of direct HIV infection of the gut.

 

The diagnosis of HIV infection in infants born to HIV-infected mothers is done using various methods, including HIV proviral DNA or RNA PCR, HIV culture, or HIV p24 antigen. The national program now uses an HIV total nucleic acid (RNA + proviral DNA) PCR test on dried blood spot samples. All positive tests need to be confirmed with an HIV PCR test on another sample.

 

Infants born to HIV-positive mothers should be exclusively breastfed or fed with replacement feeds exclusively until 6 months of age. Infants should also receive AR prophylaxis with syrup nevirapine or zidovudine.

 

It is common for HIV-infected infants to experience gastrointestinal tract involvement, with bacteria (Salmonella, Campylobacter, Shigella, Mycobacterium avium complex), protozoa (Giardia, Cryptosporidium, Isospora, microsporidia), viruses (CMV, HSV, rotavirus), and fungi (Candida) being common pathogens. MAC and protozoal infections tend to be the most severe and prolonged in children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Test stool for giardiasis and give antibiotics: This is not the preferred immediate next step. First, the diagnosis of HIV infection should be established before treating secondary infections.

 

Option C. Antibody tests for HIV: Antibody tests for HIV are not useful in establishing the diagnosis of HIV infection in infants. This is because all infants born to HIV-infected mothers test antibodies positive at birth due to the passive transfer of maternal HIV antibodies across the placenta. It can be used as a diagnostic tool after 18 months of age.

 

Option D. Aerobic culture: Aerobic culture is not used for the diagnosis of HIV infection. It is more relevant for identifying bacterial infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The next best step in diagnosing HIV in infants born to HIV-positive mothers is to perform an HIV DNA PCR test using a dried blood spot sample.

questions.text: Implantation of the fertilized ovum typically occurs on which day post-fertilization? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Day 5

 

Explanation:

 

Implantation typically occurs between the 6th to 10th day post-fertilization. According to embryological references such as Langevin and Larson, implantation generally begins around the 5th to 6th day. However, in this specific question, since Day 6 is not listed among the options, the best available choice is Day 5, which aligns closely with the actual timing of implantation onset.

 

During early embryogenesis, the blastocyst stage, which is the stage right before implantation, is typically reached around Day 5. At this point, the blastocyst is ready to implant into the uterine wall, initiating the process of establishing pregnancy.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Implantation typically begins around the 5th to 6th day after fertilization, with Day 5 often representing the initial attachment of the blastocyst to the uterine lining. If Day 6 is not an option, choose the next closest day, which is Day 5.

questions.text: What renal function does the formula UV/P represent? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clearance

 

Renal clearance is a measure of the volume of plasma from which a substance is completely removed by the kidneys per unit time. It provides important information about the efficiency with which the kidneys can filter out a substance from the bloodstream and excrete it in the urine.

 

The formula is:

 

Clearance(C) = UV /P ​

 

Where:

 

  • C is the clearance of the substance.
  • U is the concentration of the substance in the urine.
  • V is the urine flow rate (volume of urine produced per unit time).
  • P is the concentration of the substance in the plasma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Filtration fraction: This is the ratio of the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) to the renal plasma flow (RPF).

 

Option B. Tubular secretion: This refers to the active process by which substances are transported from the blood into the renal tubule. While clearance can involve secretion, the formula UV/P specifically calculates overall clearance, not just secretion.

 

Option C. Tubular reabsorption: This refers to the process by which substances are reabsorbed from the renal tubule back into the blood. The UV/P formula does not directly represent reabsorption but overall clearance, which can include filtration and reabsorption processes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The formula UV/P is used to calculate the renal clearance of a substance, reflecting the volume of plasma from which the kidneys can completely remove that substance per unit time.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with features of massive splenomegaly. On examination, his TLC was more than 85,000/mm³ with immature cells and a shift to the left with the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome. The mutation associated with the Philadelphia chromosome is? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Translocation

 

Explanation

 

Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) is characterized by the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome, which results from a balanced reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22. Specifically, the ABL1 gene on chromosome 9 is translocated to the BCR gene on chromosome 22, resulting in the BCR-ABL fusion gene. This fusion gene encodes a protein with constitutively active tyrosine kinase activity, which leads to uncontrolled cell proliferation.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Inversion: This involves a segment of a chromosome being reversed end to end. It is not associated with the formation of the Philadelphia chromosome.

 

Option C. Deletion: This refers to the loss of a chromosome segment. It is not related to the Philadelphia chromosome.

 

Option D. Insertion: This involves the addition of one or more nucleotide base pairs into a DNA sequence. It is not the mechanism behind the Philadelphia chromosome.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

The Philadelphia chromosome is the result of a balanced reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22, forming the BCR-ABL fusion gene, which is a hallmark of Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML).

questions.text: An employee who has been diagnosed with tuberculosis is eligible for an extended sickness benefit for? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 2 years

 

Under the Employees' State Insurance (ESI) Act of 1948, employees who are diagnosed with specific long-term illnesses, including tuberculosis, are eligible for an extended sickness benefit. This benefit provides financial support to cover a significant portion of their wages during prolonged periods of illness. The extended sickness benefit offers 80% of the employee's wages for up to 2 years. This provision ensures that employees have continued financial support while they are unable to work due to their medical condition.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A young man underwent a surgery on his chest after a trauma an year ago and has developed a lesion as shown. Which of the following is a probable diagnosis in the patient? (NEETPG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Keloid

 

The image and clinical history are indicative of a keloid, which is a type of raised scar that grows excessively and extends beyond the original wound boundaries.

 

Keloid:

 

  • Definition: Keloids are overgrowths of scar tissue that develop around a wound, usually after the wound has healed. They are benign and result from an overproduction of collagen.
  • Appearance: Keloids are raised, thick, and can be pink, red, or dark in color. They often grow larger than the original wound and do not regress over time.
  • Location: Commonly occur on the chest, shoulders, earlobes, and cheeks but can appear anywhere on the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemangioma: Hemangiomas are benign tumors made up of blood vessels. They usually appear as red or purple marks and are often present at birth or develop shortly after.

 

Option C. Normal scar: A normal scar typically lies flat against the skin and does not extend beyond the boundary of the original wound. It is usually lighter in color compared to keloids.

 

Option D. Hamartoma: Hamartomas are benign, focal malformations that resemble neoplastic tissue but grow at the same rate as the surrounding tissues. They do not typically present as raised scars.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Keloids are characterized by an excessive overgrowth of scar tissue that extends beyond the boundaries of the original wound, often appearing thick and raised. They are more common in areas such as the chest, shoulders, earlobes, and cheeks. The clinical image and description provided align with the diagnosis of a keloid.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with breathlessness. She is a known case of rheumatic heart disease. On examination, the apical impulse is hyperdynamic, and a "pistol shot" sound is heard over the femoral artery. The pulse is collapsing and water hammer-like. Auscultation reveals a pansystolic murmur and an early diastolic murmur. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aortic regurgitation + Mitral regurgitation

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical features suggest a combined valvular lesion with predominant aortic regurgitation (AR) and mitral regurgitation (MR):

 

  • Pistol shot sounds (also called Traube’s sign or pistol shot femorals)
  • Collapsing/water hammer pulse (Watson’s water hammer pulse)
  • Early diastolic murmur – Characteristic of AR
  • Pansystolic murmur – Characteristic of MR
  • Hyperdynamic apex – Seen in volume overload conditions like AR and MR
  • History of rheumatic heart disease, which commonly affects the mitral and aortic valves

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mitral stenosis + Mitral regurgitation: Incorrect because:

 

  • MS produces a mid-diastolic murmur, not early diastolic
  • MS does not cause collapsing pulse or pistol shot sounds
  • MS typically causes a tapping apex, not hyperdynamic

 

Option C. Mitral stenosis + Aortic regurgitation: Incorrect because:

 

  • No mid-diastolic murmur of MS described
  • Pansystolic murmur indicates MR, not MS

 

Option D. Mitral regurgitation + Aortic stenosis: Incorrect because:

 

  • AS produces an ejection systolic murmur, not early diastolic
  • AS does not cause collapsing pulse or pistol shot sounds
  • AS typically causes a sustained apex beat, not hyperdynamic

 

Educational Objective:

 

The characteristic clinical features of combined aortic regurgitation and mitral regurgitation include:

 

  • Early diastolic murmur (AR)
  • Pansystolic murmur (MR)
  • Pistol shot sounds and water hammer pulse (AR)
  • Hyperdynamic apex (volume overload)

questions.text: A Patient had dietary Cu deficiency, which is required by lysyl oxidase to cross link the collagen, what is the diagnosis of the patient? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Menkes Disease


Menkes disease is caused by copper deficiency. Copper is required as a cofactor for lysyl oxidase, an enzyme necessary for collagen cross-linking. In Menkes disease, there is a defect in the ATP7A protein which is responsible for copper absorption. This leads to copper deficiency despite adequate dietary intake. In Menkes disease, copper deficiency is seen and lysyl oxidase is affected which results in defective and weak collagen synthesis leading to brittle hair.

 

Other Options: 


Option B. Scoliosis: This is an abnormal lateral curvature of the spine, not directly related to copper deficiency or lysyl oxidase function. Scoliosis can have various causes including congenital, neuromuscular, or idiopathic factors.

 

Option C. Ehlers Danlos syndrome: This is a group of connective tissue disorders caused by defects in collagen synthesis or structure. In Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, the defect is in lysyl hydroxylase, particularly in the kyphoscoliotic type, not in lysyl oxidase.

 

Option D. Scurvy: This is caused by vitamin C deficiency, not copper deficiency. Vitamin C is required for collagen maturation through hydroxylation of proline and lysine, but this is a different process from the cross-linking function performed by lysyl oxidase that requires copper.

 

Educational Objective: 


Menkes disease is caused by copper deficiency which affects lysyl oxidase activity, an enzyme required for collagen cross-linking, resulting in weak collagen formation and characteristic symptoms including brittle hair.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with a history of vomiting within 3 hours of consumption of food at a party. Which of the following organism is most likely to cause these symptoms? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Staphylococcus aureus

 

The most likely causative organism in the given scenario is Staphylococcus aureus. It causes food poisoning within 30 minutes to 6 hours after consumption of the contaminated food.

 

The common sources of infection are the foods that are not cooked after handling. These include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches. Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhoea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clostridium botulinum: Causes botulism, typically presenting with symptoms such as muscle weakness, paralysis, and respiratory failure rather than rapid-onset vomiting.

 

Option C. Clostridium perfringens: Associated with gastroenteritis that causes abdominal cramps and diarrhea, typically occurring 8-16 hours after consumption of contaminated food.

 

Option D. Salmonella typhi: Causes typhoid fever, characterized by prolonged fever, abdominal pain, and other systemic symptoms, rather than immediate vomiting.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: All the following are functions of the superior oblique muscle except? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adduction

 

The superior oblique muscle is one of the extraocular muscles responsible for controlling eye movements. Its primary functions include:

 

  • Abduction: Moving the eyeball away from the midline of the body. The superior oblique helps in turning the eye outward.
  • Depression: Moving the eyeball downward. The superior oblique assists in looking down, especially when the eye is in an adducted position.
  • Intorsion: Rotating the top of the eye towards the nose. This is the action of rotating the eyeball towards the nose, which is an inward rotation.

 

These functions can be remembered using the mnemonic "SOLID," where:

 

  • Superior Oblique LID stands for Lateral (abduction), Intorsion, and Depression.

 

The superior oblique muscle does not perform adduction, which is moving the eyeball towards the midline of the body. This action is typically performed by the recti muscles, specifically the medial rectus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The superior oblique muscle is responsible for abduction, depression, and intorsion of the eye, but not adduction.

choices.text: Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs)
Functional ovarian cyst
Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)

questions.text: Which of the following is a risk factor for progression to borderline ovarian tumor? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nulliparity

 

Nulliparity is associated with a slightly increased risk of ovarian tumors, including borderline ovarian tumors, possibly due to uninterrupted ovulation and hormonal fluctuations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs: Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are known to reduce the risk of ovarian cancer.

 

Option B. Functional ovarian cyst: Functional ovarian cysts typically do not progress to ovarian tumors.

 

Option D. Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS): Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) has not been strongly linked with increased risk of borderline ovarian tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nulliparity is recognized as a risk factor for borderline ovarian tumors, highlighting the influence of reproductive factors on ovarian health.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of inherited Thrombophilia? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Factor V Leiden mutation

 

Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited cause of thrombophilia. This genetic mutation makes Factor V resistant to inactivation by activated Protein C, leading to increased thrombotic risk. It is an autosomal dominant disorder and is particularly common in individuals of European descent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Protein C deficiency: Less common than Factor V Leiden; leads to increased thrombotic risk

 

Option B. Prothrombin deficiency: A rare inherited coagulation disorder that typically causes bleeding

 

Option D. Antithrombin III deficiency: Relatively rare inherited thrombophilic condition

 

Educational Objective:

 

Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited cause of thrombophilia.

questions.text: In a case of alcohol abuse, blood during autopsy is preserved in: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sodium fluoride

 

In cases of alcohol abuse, proper preservation of blood during autopsy is crucial for accurate toxicological analysis.

 

Sodium fluoride is the preservative of choice for body fluids such as blood, urine, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), and vitreous humor. Sodium fluoride prevents the fermentation of alcohol in the blood sample, ensuring that the alcohol concentration remains stable and can be accurately measured.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rectified spirit: While rectified spirit is used for preserving viscera and is considered the best for that purpose, it is not suitable for preserving blood samples intended for toxicological analysis.

 

Option C. Sodium chloride: Saturated solutions of common salt (sodium chloride) are used for preserving viscera, not blood. They do not prevent fermentation of alcohol in blood samples.

 

Option D. Formalin: Formalin is used for histopathology to preserve tissues. However, it hardens the tissues, making it unsuitable for toxicological analysis as it complicates the extraction of substances like alcohol from the sample.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For the preservation of blood/ any body fluids – Sodium fluoride

 

Esp. for Blood – NaF OR Potassium oxalates as anticoagulants    

    

Esp. for Urine – NaF OR Thymol

 

For the preservation of Viscera - Saturated solutions of sodium chloride (MC), Rectified spirit (best to use)

choices.text: Skin lesions and bruises of various ages are seen on the body
It occurs due to the tendency of a child to fall repeatedly
The syndrome is a result of gun injuries

questions.text: Identify the true statement from the following about battered baby syndrome? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Skin lesions and bruises of various ages are seen on the body

 

Battered child syndrome is defined as the collection of injuries sustained by a child as a result of repeated mistreatment or beating. If a child's injuries indicate intentional trauma or appear to be more severe than could reasonably be expected to result from an accident, battered child syndrome should be suspected.

 

Skin lesions and bruises of different ages (from young to old) are a classical feature of a child with battered baby syndrome.

 

Skeletal survey helps in identifying bone injuries in Battered Baby syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It occurs due to the tendency of a child to fall repeatedly: False: While children do fall frequently, the pattern and severity of injuries in battered child syndrome are inconsistent with typical childhood falls and accidents.

 

Option C. Stab wounds are obvious: False: Stab wounds are not a common feature of battered child syndrome. The syndrome primarily involves bruises, fractures, and other signs of physical abuse.

 

Option D. The syndrome is a result of gun injuries: False: Battered child syndrome is not characterized by gun injuries. It involves repeated physical abuse, leading to various types of trauma, particularly bruises and fractures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Battered child syndrome is characterized by the presence of skin lesions and bruises of different ages, indicating repeated and ongoing physical abuse.
